Recent research has shown that exercise monitoring systems that use computer vision technology can be effective in promoting physical activity in older adults. For example, a study by Choi and colleagues (2020) evaluated the feasibility and effectiveness of a computer vision-based exercise intervention in community-dwelling older adults. The intervention included a tablet-based exercise program that used a camera to provide real-time feedback and correction to participants during exercise. The results showed significant improvements in exercise adherence and physical function in the intervention group compared to the control group.

Another study by Kwon and colleagues (2021) developed and evaluated a computer vision-based exercise monitoring system for older adults with cognitive impairments. The system used a camera and machine learning algorithms to recognize and track exercise movements and provide feedback to participants. The results showed that the system was feasible and acceptable to both participants and caregivers, and was effective in improving exercise adherence and physical function.

In terms of technical approaches, several studies have proposed different methods for recognizing and tracking exercise movements using computer vision technology. For example, a study by Panwar and colleagues (2020) developed a deep learning-based system that used pose estimation and motion analysis to recognize exercise movements and provide real-time feedback to participants. The results showed that the system was effective in detecting exercise movements with high accuracy and providing meaningful feedback to users.

Another study by Ahmad and colleagues (2018) proposed a vision-based system that used markerless motion capture and machine learning techniques to recognize and classify exercise movements. The system was evaluated using a dataset of exercise videos and achieved high accuracy in recognizing different types of exercises.

Overall, these studies highlight the potential of exercise monitoring systems using computer vision technology for promoting physical activity and improving the health and well-being of older adults. However, there are still some challenges and limitations that need to be addressed, such as the need for more diverse and representative datasets, the need for more user-friendly and accessible systems, and the need for more rigorous evaluation studies in real-world settings.
